Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Determinants of the spread of beneficial fungi and their relation to invasion by non-native pine trees
Award.AbstractNarration:
Biological invasions create enormous environmental and social problems, impose a huge economic cost, and threaten biodiversity. Studying invasions aids environmental management and increases understanding of natural system dynamics. Fungi are one of the least understood groups of invasive species, despite being an essential component of biodiversity and having tremendous ecological significance. Fungal control of plant invasion will be studied on an island in Argentina where a century ago more than 130 exotic trees species were planted, including many that are highly invasive elsewhere. Surprisingly few of these species have become widespread on this island. Previous research shows that lack of mycorrhizal fungi (root symbionts that are key to plant survival) limits spread of invasive plant species in the area. These fungi form mutualisms with only a few plant species, and the plants and the fungi are dispersed independently, so the plants may not 'find' mutualistic fungi. This project will elucidate how fungal dispersal aids spread of invasive trees. Introduced species that eat fungi, such as European boar and deer, may disperse fungi in their feces, generating a feedback between the exotics and increasing the impacts of the invading trees. Fungi can also spread belowground and thus promote establishment of the introduced trees. This project will show how mammals, wind, and belowground growth influence fungal spread and subsequent invasion by exotic conifers, one of the most aggressive groups of invasive plants.

The 21st century may bring a great loss of biodiversity. Invasive species are a leading factor, also producing huge economic losses. To manage biological invasions effectively to minimize these environmental and economic costs, we must understand the factors regulating invasions: this is the goal of this study. In addition, this will contribute to our understanding of fungal biology and its influence on plant ecology, which will advance the ecological sciences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We are witnessing a great loss of biodiversity this century.  Invasive species are a leading factor, also producing huge economic losses.  To manage biological invasions effectively we must gain a better understanding of the factors controlling invasions, the primary goal of this project. Pine species and Douglas-fir are common conifers in many North American forests. While they do not occur naturally in South America they have been introduced for their timber in many countries in the Southern Hemisphere. Unfortunately, they are invading out of plantations and considered some of the world’s worst invasive species. Previous investigations have revealed many factors that contribute to the invasion biology of these trees but the role of soil microbes has not been addressed. This project focused on ectomycorrhizal fungi in conifer invasions occurring in South America.

The primary location for our work was on an island in Argentina where pine and Douglas-fir were not invading into native Nothofagus stands (Southern beech). Although spores of mycorrhizal fungi compatible with the conifers were in soils of exotic plantations, they were not in soils in native forests surrounding the plantations. Seed planted outside the plantations germinated and died unless they were within 10 meters of the plantation edge. However, if soil from plantations was added to the planting holes outside the plantations the seedlings established and grew well. We found that nonnative ectomycorrhizal fungi from the plantations always colonized the established seedlings. The lack of invasion on this island was due to a lack of compatible mycorrhizal fungi in soils outside the plantations beyond the invasion front.

Our next objective then was to investigate why spores were not dispersing very far out of the plantations. We observed that 90% of the spores captured on the ground near ectomycorrhizal mushrooms fell within a one-meter horizontal radius around the cap. We also measured spore dispersal in the vertical direction above the caps and again found most spores were trapped within a one meter radius from the cap. We concluded that the majority of spores disperse locally and predict spores do disperse over great distances via wind, but as an increasingly diffuse spore rain.

We also investigated spore dispersal via mammals. We found that native mammals at our island site did not eat nonnative mushrooms fruiting in the plantations but recently introduced nonnative mammals (European deer and boar) did. Fecal pellets from nonnative mammals collected in the area were successfully used as ectomycorrhizal inoculant for pine and Douglas-fir seedlings. Therefore, as previous work had shown, introducing seed of Pinaceae alone does not lead to an invasion. However, introducing nonnative seed of Pinaceae, nonnative ectomycorrhizal fungi and nonnative mammal dispersers leads to an invasion in a nice example of an invasional meltdown involving multiple species.

Fungi observed in the Argentina studies are typical fungi observed on conifers in disturbance and primary successional settings in their native range: Suillus, Rhizopogon, Hebeloma, Inocybe and members of Thelephoraceae. In a related study from Chile we found that pine invasion was facilitated by a single species of fungus, Suillus luteus. Even though other species were present in the Chilean plantations, Suillus luteus was often the only fungus found on trees far from plantations. This is intriguing because native stands of pines typically have tens if not hundreds of mycorrhizal fungi supporting the trees and here we found only one filling that niche and is itself acting as an invasive species as much as the pines (neither can invade without the other).
